text: The president of Latvia (, literally "State President") is head of state and commander-in-chief of the National Armed Forces of the Republic of Latvia. == List == ; Parties ; Status No. Name (Birth–Death) Portrait Term of office Term of office Political party 1 Jānis Čakste (1859–1927)Upon Latvian independence on 17 December 1918, Jānis Čakste was head of state as Chairman of Tautas padome (1918–20) and Speaker of the Constitutional Assembly (1920–22), until he was elected President by the first Saeima on 14 November 1922. 17 December 1918 14 November 1922 Democratic Centre 1 Jānis Čakste (1859–1927)Upon Latvian independence on 17 December 1918, Jānis Čakste was head of state as Chairman of Tautas padome (1918–20) and Speaker of the Constitutional Assembly (1920–22), until he was elected President by the first Saeima on 14 November 1922. 14 November 1922 14 March 1927 (died) Democratic Centre — Pauls Kalniņš (1872–1945)Upon Čakste's death, Speaker of the Saeima Pauls Kalniņš was acting president from 14 March 1927 to 8 April 1927. 14 March 1927 8 April 1927 Latvian Social Democratic Workers' Party 2 Gustavs Zemgals (1871–1939) 8 April 1927 4 September 1930 Democratic Centre 3 Alberts Kviesis (1881–1944) 4 September 1930 15 May 1934 Latvian Farmers' Union (3) Alberts Kviesis (1881–1944) 16 May 1934 10 April 1936 Independent 4 Kārlis Ulmanis (1877–1942)Upon the expiration of Kviesis's term, Prime minister Kārlis Ulmanis illegally merged the Presidency and the Premiership, holding both offices himself. After the Soviet occupation Prime Minister Augusts Kirhenšteins was the illegitimate Acting President from 21 July to 25 August 1940 11 April 1936 21 July 1940 Independent Occupation of Latvia (21 Latvia (21 July 1940 – 21 August 1991) Occupation of Latvia (21 July 1940 – 21 August 1991) — Anatolijs Gorbunovs (born 1942)After the restoration of Latvian independence, speaker of the Latvian parliament Anatolijs Gorbunovs was acting president from 21 August 1991 to 8 July 1993. 21 August 1991 13 February 1993 Popular Front of Latvia (—) Anatolijs Gorbunovs (born 1942)After the restoration of Latvian independence, speaker of the Latvian parliament Anatolijs Gorbunovs was acting president from 21 August 1991 to 8 July 1993. 13 February 1993 8 July 1993 Latvian Way 5 Guntis Ulmanis (born 1939) 8 July 1993 8 July 1999 Latvian Farmers' Union 6 Vaira Vīķe- Freiberga (born 1937) 8 July 1999 8 July 2007 Independent 7 Valdis Zatlers (born 1955) 8 July 2007 8 July 2011 Independent 8 Andris Bērziņš (born 1944) 8 July 2011 8 July 2015 Union of Greens and FarmersBērziņš is not a member of parties forming the Union of Greens and Farmers, however he ran for the Saeima from their list and was a member of their parliamentary group at the time of his election. 9 Raimonds Vējonis (born 1966) 8 July 2015 8 July 2019 Latvian Green Party 10 Egils Levits (born 1955) 8 July 2019 8 July 2023 Independent 11 Edgars Rinkēvičs (born 1973) 8 July 2023 Incumbent Unity ==Living former presidents== There are seven living former Latvian Presidents: File:Anatolijs_Gorbunovs_2015-05-04.jpg|Anatolijs
